results.title: Planet earth
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED

results.title: Imperial stone: the art of Rome
results.creator_credit: Bayley Silleck, Channel Four, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and TVS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Michael Wood and Richard Brilliant look at Roman architecture which embodied the austere ideals of this conquering empire. The discovery and use of concrete and the development of architectural forms based on the keystone arch is highlighted as these had a significant effect on building design in Europe. The Panthenon is seen as a landmark structure and the transition of pagan symbols and forms into Early Christian society is discussed.

results.title: The Coast: a question of balance
results.creator_credit: David Hughes, Dept of the Navy and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Filmed on location at Mornington Peninsula, Bellarine Peninsula, Apollo Bay, Torquay, Westernport Bay and Port Melbourne, this film is designed to alert students to the conflict inherent in man’s use of the coastal system, potentially one of the most fragile of environments. Shows the abuse of the sand dune systems through leisure, sport, traffic and the erection of structures, as well as the heavy demands placed by industry and shipping on coastal waters. Stresses that these competing interests will, if left unchecked, ultimately destroy the delicate flora and fauna balance of the coastal system. Music performed by Pink Floyd - “Be careful with that axe, Eugene” Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Classical idea
results.creator_credit: Bayley Silleck and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on the art of the Western classical world. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the origins of humanism and classical works of ancient Greece as well as Roman architecture and engineering. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context, this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: The Cloudmaker
results.creator_credit: Leah Miller, Pieter Van Deusen and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Animation, in which a tiny figure struggling in a gigantic electro-mechanical world challenges the viewer to think about how one can live, work and fit into, and find satisfaction in a large technological society. No commentary, music soundtrack only.

results.title: The Close World - The Building
results.brief_description:
Learning to collaborate with the non-human will soon be an essential skill. ‘The Building’ is part five of an ongoing series of works, The Close World, an experiment of fantasy world-building in collaboration with human and non-human actors. Written in collaboration with OpenAI’s GPT-3 trained on key texts of fantasy and philosophy of language, ‘The Building’ is realised in 3D sound and vision by Daniel Jenatsch, performed by artist and philosopher Franziska Aigner and brought to the world by full stack web developer Tim Busuttil. In the spirit of collaboration, ‘The Building’ explores the imaginative capacity of AI and it’s unique voice in intersection with our own.

The Close World – The Building is a further iteration of a larger body of work by Daniel Jenatsch. This is the first time Jenatsch has ever considered making a playable video-based work, and he imagines that different iterations and further developments of ‘The Building’ will be released at different times across the exhibition period.

results.title: The Cleo Laine collection
results.creator_credit: Graeme Rowland, Bill Ramsey and de Montignie Productions
results.brief_description: Recorded live at the Melbourne Concert Hall in 1986, this video presents the sensuous and sultry jazz and blues singer Cleo Laine performing with her husband John Dankworth and the Dankworth Quartet. British born Cleo Laine began her musical career in the early 1950s where she met and married renowned musician John Dankworth in 1958. Together they have toured the world (and still currently touring) but Cleo has also tried her hand at acting on the stage in such plays as “Flesh to a tiger”, “A Midsummer night’s dream” and the title role in Ibsen’s “Hedda Gabler” among many other performances. Songs from this Melbourne concert by this great lady include “Free and easy”, “I love you just the way you are”, “Crazy rhythm”, “Send in the clowns”, “He was beautiful”.
